title: demo: improve endpoint configuration
body:
Right now you have to edit the `js/main.js` file to change the url endpoint used for the demo. This config should be moved to _site.yml and be easy to overwrite for local development.

Problems:
* Seems like `.js` files are not interpreted as templates by jekyll, so `{{ site.demo.url }}` isn't accessible
* Jekyll seems to have no concept of environment configs, so we'll have to come up with something for that ourselves.

This is not urgent, but a nice to have.

title: Better error message when Content-Length does not match Content-Range
body: Right now it gives a 500 error with the explanation EOF which is confusing

title: Streamable file downloads
body: Right now GET \<fileUrl\> doesn't work until the full file is received. It'd be awesome if it would stream the amount of data that has been received so far, so that data can be streamed to the downloader as it's being uploaded!

title: add integration tests
body: This depends on #9, once we have things refactored, we could easily spin up a test server for integration tests.

title: refactor / clean up
body: The current code could need a little more structure / types, which would also help with testing.

title: add logging
body: this way we can tell what files were uploaded, how fast, etc.

title: Setup JSHint checking
body: Or any other good static analyzer that is less bitchy than JSLint.

title: jQuery File upload research
body:
- setup locally with node server for now
- upload file locally via jquery file upload
- is it able to upload several chunks at the same time?
- how can we identify files:
  - what data do we get? path, size, mime, name -> generate unique id
  - id of tus, file upload

title: Support streams with unknown length?
body: see discussion here: http://www.tus.io/protocols/resumable-upload.html#comment-865108402

title: Clarify that POST is an optional step
body: If you already have the final file url, you can directly PUT to it.

title: PATCH vs PUT
body: As pointed out by @Baughn in IRC, PATCH (partial entity update) seems more appropriate than PUT (replacing an entire entity) for resuming uploads. But it might cause issues with mobile http proxies as PATCH is somewhat exotic. Needs investigation.

title: Define behavior for GET on incomplete uploads
body:
Edge case. Don't really have a strong opinion on whether it should simply return **404 Not Found** or give some sort of indication that an upload is under way, like **416 Requested Range Not Satisfiable**. For the latter, the RFC says servers "SHOULD" respond with 416 if a *Range* header was sent in the request but it doesn't say anything about it not being allowed or recommended otherwise.

Probably best to just leave a small note on the protocol draft stating that default behavior is to report 404 until the upload has been completed but server implementations are free to roll in their own behavior as they deem fit.

title: Consider using 204 No Content
body: See: https://news.ycombinator.com/reply?id=5564024&whence=item%3fid%3d5563569

title: Clarify that url does not have to be fixed
body: see https://news.ycombinator.com/reply?id=5563688&whence=item%3fid%3d5563569

title: Mention authentication in protocol
body: Basically clarifying that the usual suspects can be used (basic auth, cookies, etc).

title: 100-Continue Research
body: Figure out if we need to support / require https' 100-Continue feature.

title: Checksum Support (MD5,CRC32,SHA1,etc.)
body:
Just a vague idea I'm throwing out here:

Should there be some mechanism for verifying the upload contents somewhere in the process? e.g supplying a md5 hash of the file when responding to a `HEAD` request?
Or is this outside the scope of the protocol and something that should left as option for implementations to handle if they want to?

title: make example urls in protocol work
body: we host a tusd version anyway, why not make life easier for early protocol implementors by making the example requests executable

title: Define behaviour when uploading non-contiguous chunks
body:
As per IRC convo:

Should the server accept uploading of non-contiguous chunks?
For example client uploads ranges [0-100], then [240-360] then [400-420]. Do we accept this happily or throw toys out of the pram?


If acceptable behaviour, how should results of such be displayed when making a `HEAD` request?

with contiguous blocks `Range: bytes=0-100`
with non-contigous blocks `Range: bytes=0-100,240-360,400-420` ?? _no idea if this is sane or not_

title: "Range" vs. "Content-Range"
body:
"Range" is a **request** header for GET requests in [section 14.35](http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.35) of the HTTP/1.1 spec:

> HTTP retrieval requests using conditional or unconditional GET methods
> MAY request one or more sub-ranges of the entity

On the other hand, "Content-Range" in [section 14.16](http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.16) of the spec is a **response** header field:

> The Content-Range entity-header is sent with a partial entity-body to specify
> where in the full entity-body the partial body should be applied

Why do you use "Range" for the response and "Content-Range" for the request?
